content:
I made a little video about how I modified Zulip's color scheme:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1DA4bt8k06U
I considered posting this to #frontend, but I decided to post this here for kind of a subtle reason.

In an ideal design environment, Zulip would have a totally simple API to modify DOM. And then developers would write directly to that API in JS. Designers could use simple Tamper Monkey scripts to flesh out design ideas.
This will all make more sense if you watch the video.
Here is the repo in which I simulate a fake Zulip client: https://github.com/showell/fake_zulip

Hey everybody, I have done some live coding exercises in the past that were pretty well received. In all the prior times, I would narrate over Zulip. Tonight I did one in video form, and I posted it to YouTube:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=usButzJh0XU&feature=youtu.be
If folks are interested, I will follow up on this one while both streaming to YT and narrating on Zulip.
In the above video I work on my tamper-monkey script to traverse the Zulip DOM and apply a new color scheme. (The first video that I link to in this topic gives more context.)

Here is another session from this morning:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TxTRaMItBOU&feature=youtu.be
